results.title: Australia : land of the shark
results.creator_credit: Osford Film Productions, Beyond Productions, Andrew Wight and Liz Wight
results.brief_description: A quest for the truth about the behaviour of the Great White Shark, filmed in the remote waters off the South Australian coast. With an array of planned experiments and special equipment, including a custom built shark ‘sub’ , this film captures a host of extraordinary and sometimes frightening interactions with the king of the ocean.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Osford Film Productions, Beyond Productions, Andrew Wight and Liz Wight

results.title: Australia & company unlimited
results.brief_description: A commentary, expressing faith in Australia’s future, illustrated by various scenes from national life - mainly primary and secondary industries. This film was made for the Ford Motor Company of Australia.

results.title: Australia - Colony to Nation
results.brief_description:
Australian Aboriginals sail down a river to be followed by white people from England. People from other nations begin to make their journeys to Australia and the film ends with the Olympic flag and people from all nationalities gathered around it.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Australia's wonderful wildlife
results.creator_credit: GEO Wildlife Documentaries and Grant Young
results.brief_description: The Australian continent has been isolate for a very long time and its animal inhabitants have evolved in isolation to produce a wildlife community very different from that found anywhere else in the world. This video is a sample of Australia’s unique fauna, with 60 seconds of footage on each animal. Some of the animals will be familiar to everyone, others are not so familiar, but all are distinctively Australian. Animals discussed include: Platypus; Koala; Emu; Kookaburra; Taipan and the Shingleback.

results.title: Australia's urban wildlife
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Conservation, ABC-TV (Australia), Janet Lane and Deborah Boerne
results.brief_description: As seen on the ABC’s “Behind The News” program, this video looks at the ways in which Australia’s native wildlife habitat has been altered by urban development. It also examines the ways in which students and teachers can learn about and value their local fauna. “Our hidden neighbours” is an introduction to native wildlife in urban areas and highlights the effect of urban development on wildlife. “Nocturnal visitors” looks at some of the native nocturnal wildlife found in urban areas. “The Feral menace” explores the problems that introduced animal species have caused for native wildlife. “Attracting wildlife” shows ways of attracting wildlife to your own backyard.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Conservation, ABC-TV (Australia), Janet Lane and Deborah Boerne

results.title: Australia's soldier tradesmen.
results.creator_credit: Department of Army Public Relations and Geoffrey Thompson
results.brief_description: The Army Apprentice School at Balcombe, Victoria. The variety of specialist trade training, including trade drawing, woodworking, building, telecommunications, automotive engineering and clerical training. The general educational facilities, sports and basic military training. How the Army Apprentice Scheme offers young men a full life, financial independence and first-class technical qualifications. Narrated by Keith Eden.

results.title: Australia's Secret Heroes
results.brief_description: Australia’s Secret Heroes uncovers a dramatic forgotten episode of Australia’s World War II involvement. Combining penetrating big-picture history of the Pacific war with gripping personal narrative, it charts the journey of Z Special, a covert jungle warfare unit and forerunner of today’s special force units.

constellations_other.name: Australia and WW2
constellations_other.description: A constellation exploring representations of Australians during World War 2.

results.title: Australia's religions communities: a multimedia exploration (PC & MAC)
results.creator_credit: Christian Research Association and Redfish Bluefish (Creative)
results.brief_description: The nature of religion in Australia is changing. Over the last 200 years, millions of immigrants have brought to Australia a great range of religious traditions. Since 1946, that diversity has increased all the more rapidly. All the major religious traditions of the world may now be found in Australia. At the same time, several other trends are evident. Australians are making choices about their spirituality in ways they have never done before. They are trying out the variety of options found in Australia, and drawing on the various resources. Many have detached themselves from specific religious organisations, but most continue to value the spiritual dimension of life and put together their own sense of spirituality and meaning. There is new awareness of the spiritual heritage of the Aboriginal people particularly in relationship to the land. This CD-ROM explores the world of faiths and meaning and includes all the major religions plus many of the lesser known, smaller alternative religions. It will help you explore your own traditions and background, the heritages of your neighbours and friends, and Australian history and the dynamics of contemporary society.

results.title: Australia's refugee dilemma
results.creator_credit: Video Education Australasia, ABC-TV (Australia) and Neil Barrett
results.brief_description: The United Nations definition of refugees: “People who are (1) outside their country of nationality or their usual country of residence, and (2) are unable or unwilling to return to that country due to a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group, or political opinion.” Australia takes in many refugees legally and illegally, from all over the world, but in recent times the majority of would be refugees, or asylum seekers, come from Iraq, Iran and Afghanistan and more often than not, have been smuggled across the seas in run-down fishing boats from Indonesia. In desperation, these asylum seekers are escaping from persecution either by the brutal regime of Saddam Hussein or the repressive rule of the Taliban and see Australia as the country which will offer them sanctuary, freedom of speech and religion. However, since September 2001, the Australian Government has passed legislation and the “Pacific Solution” to prevent asylum seekers reaching Australia - any that successfully reach our shores without the correct paperwork face mandatory detention. This program, with a 2002 update, combines television footage from ABC “Four corners” and “7.30 Report” including interviews with refugees, Philip Ruddock (Minister for Immigration) and John Olsen (the then Premier of South Australia) among others, with discussion on the situation of asylum seekers, legal and illegal, the rules for obtaining protection and temporary protection visas and the Australian Government’s position on this vexing and controversial issue. Suitable for Years 9-12 Secondary and Tertiary students. Teacher notes included
